titleStmt.title: Ductile Nb alloys with reduced density and cost

analytic.title: Ductile Nb alloys with reduced density and cost

biblStruct.note: Received 23 April 2019 Received in revised form 1 July 2019 Accepted 2 August 2019

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Refractory alloys Nb alloys Microstructure Compression properties

div.p: Several Nb-based alloys containing Ti, Mo and W were produced and their microstructure, phase composition and mechanical properties in the temperature range of 23e1200 C were reported and compared with a high-strength commercial Nb alloy C-3009, which contains Hf and W alloying elements. Replacement of Hf with Ti and W with Mo led to alloys with considerably reduced density and cost, as well as with reduced micro-segregation of the alloying elements. The strengthening effect from W was higher than from Mo at temperatures above ~600 C and more amount of Mo was required to compensate the strength decrease. The strengthening effects from Hf and Ti were comparable at temperatures up to 1000 C; however, at 1200 C the effect from Hf was superior. It was concluded that the NbeMoeTi system can be used as a baseline for the development of high strength, high-temperature alloys using alloying with other elements.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Nb-based refractory alloys currently used in some hightemperature engine applications contain expensive and dense alloying elements [1]. For example, C-103, which is one of the most commonly used medium-strength Nb alloys, contains (by wt.%) 10 Hf, 0.5 Ta, 0.5 W, 0.7 Zr and 1 Ti; and a high strength C-3009 contains 30 Hf and 9 W. Hf, Ta and Zr are expensive, costing approximately $1200, $290 and $150 per kilogram, respectively, and Hf, W and Ta have high density of, respectively, 13.21, 16.65 and 19.25 g/ cm 3 (Table 1). Moreover, these alloys have poor oxidation resistance above 600 C. It would therefore be beneficial to develop less expensive and lower density Nb alloys, which would have structural properties, such as high temperature strength and oxidation resistance, equivalent or better than those of the currently used commercial Nb alloys. There has been extensive research on Nb alloys containing Si, whose main goal is to improve both high temperature strength and oxidation resistance [2e6]; however, NbeSi alloys are generally brittle at temperatures 1000 C and they have not found practical use yet. Refractory complex concentrated alloys (RCCAs) is another promising direction of research resulting in developing several multi-principal element alloys (MPEAs) with attractive high temperature mechanical properties and improved oxidation resistance [7]. The main challenge is the lack of experimental data, as well as valid theoretical models, on thermodynamic, mechanical and physical properties of these complex MPEA systems. RCCAs experience slow kinetics of phase transformations and may contain metastable phases. Thus extensive studies are required to identify equilibrium phase diagrams, kinetics of phase transformations and phase stability in these alloys in the time-temperature-stress conditions of practical interest [8,9].

In this work, we used conventional methods for alloy development and produced several Nb-based alloys, which contain Mo, W and Ti. A high-strength commercial Nb alloy C-3009 was used as a baseline material and the new alloys were produced by replacing heavy W and Hf with lower density Mo and Ti, respectively. Mo belongs to the same group (VI) of the periodic table as W and Ti to the same group (IV) as Hf. In addition to decreasing density, Ti is known to noticeably improve oxidation resistance of Nb [12,13]. However, Mo and Ti have lower melting temperatures than W and Hf. In addition, Mo has smaller elastic moduli than W but Ti has higher elastic moduli than Hf. Because the strength of the alloys generally increases with increasing in melting temperature and elastic moduli, replacement of W with Mo may reduce high temperature strength relative to C-3009, while the effect from replacement of Hf with Ti is not straightforward. Thus, the effect of the concentration of the alloying elements on high temperature properties has also been studied in this work.

div.head: Experimental procedures
div.p: A C-3009 alloy was received from ATI Wah-Chang, Inc. in the form of an as-cast ingot. NbeWeTi (W1), NbeMoeTi (M1, M2, M3 and M4) and NbeMoeWeTi (MW1) alloys were prepared from high purity (99.9% or higher) metals by vacuum arc melting. The elemental compositions of the alloys were determined using X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy and are shown in Table 2. The alloy density was measured using a helium pycnometer, with the accuracy of ±0.005 g/cm 3 . Vickers microhardness was determined as an average value of 10 measurements using a diamond pyramid applied to a polished surface of the alloy sample at 500 g load for 10 s. X-ray diffraction was conducted using Cu K a1 radiation in the 2q range of 10e120 . Microstructure and chemical composition were studied using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with backscatter electron and energy dispersive spectroscopy detectors.

Compression mechanical tests were conducted at 23 C, 600 C, 800 C, 1000 C and 1200 C at a constant ram speed of 0.008 mm/s that corresponded to the initial strain rate of 0.001 s À1 . Compression specimens had a squared cross-section of 5 mm Â 5 mm and the height of 8 mm. Special grinding tools were used to make the samples with parallel load surfaces and right-angle edge surfaces. Room temperature tests were conducted in air and high-temperature tests were conducted in vacuum of ~2 10 À3 Pa. The temperature setting for high-temperature compression testing consisted of heating at 50 C/min to a test temperature, holding at the temperature for 15 min, deformation with 50e55% height reduction (or until fracture, if it occurred first) and cooling at the initial cooling rate of 100 C/min or the rate of furnace cooling, whichever was slower. To calculate a true sample displacement during loading, the following procedure was used. At a given testing temperature, the response of the loading system (machine frame, load cell, dies, etc.), without a sample, was first measured by registering displacement Dl m as a function of the applied load P. Then a sample was placed between the dies and the displacement Dl sys for the system with the sample was registered as a function of the applied load P at the same temperature and ram speed. After that, at every registered P i values, the sample upset values Dl i (P i ) were calculated as Dl (P i ) ¼ Dl sys (P i ) e Dl m (P i ). The true strain was finally calculated as ln (1-Dl/l o ) and true stress was calculated as P (1-Dl/l o )/A o , where l o and A o are the initial height and initial cross-section area of the sample. Room temperature deformation and elastic behavior of the samples was additionally recorded using Vic-Gage software by Correlated Solutions [14] and good agreement between these two methods was found. The room temperature elastic modulus values reported in this work were measured using Vic-Gauge software.

div.head: Microstructure and alloy density
div.p: According to X-ray diffraction, all the studied alloys are singlephase BCC structures (Fig. 1). The lattice parameters a mes measured for the studied alloys are given in Table 3. It is found that a mes is composition-dependent and has direct correlation with the atomic radii and concentrations of the alloying elements. For example, replacing larger Hf (alloy C-3009) with smaller Ti (alloy W1) decreases a mes from 334.2 pm to 327.3m, and increasing the concentration of Mo, which is smaller than Nb and Ti, decreases a mes from 329.5 pm to 326.5 pm in alloys M1-M3. The measured a mes values are compared with the respective a ROM values calculated using the rule of mixtures (ROM) of the alloying elements:
div.formula: a ROM ¼ X c i a i ¼ 4 ffiffiffi 3 p X c i r i(1)
div.p: In Equation ( 1), c i and r i are the atomic fraction and atomic radius of an alloying element i taken from Tables 2 and1, respectively, and a i ¼ 4 ffiffi ffi 3 p r i is the BCC lattice parameter of element i [15,16]. The calculated a ROM values are given in Table 3. It can be seen that a mes are from 0.13% (for M1) to 1.62% (MW1) higher than a ROM , with a larger difference for more concentrated alloys, indicating bond shortening in the alloys relative to pure metals.

The C-3009, W1 and M1 alloys have coarse grain structures, with the average grain size over 1.5 mm (Fig. 2aec). A dendritic structure is clearly seen in the W-containing C-3009 and W1 (Fig. 2a andb). The light regions are rich in W and darker regions are rich in Hf (in C-3009) or Ti (in W1). Large difference in the atomic numbers of W and Ti provided stronger contrast between dendritic and interdendritic regions in W1 when compared to C-3009, in which W and Hf had smaller difference in the atomic numbers. The dendritic structure is absent in M1, which contains Mo instead of W. The chemical micro-segregation of the alloying elements between dendrites and interdendritic regions may change the local lattice parameter of the BCC crystal structure of the alloys. Therefore, the diffraction peak positions represent averaged distances between the respective crystal planes, because X-ray spectrums are taken from rather large surface areas, which contain many grains. In the Mo-containing alloys (M1 to M4) the average grain diameter decreases with an increase in the amount of Mo and it is 1.41 mm, 0.90 mm, 0.60 mm and 0.26 mm in M1, M2, M3 and M4 alloys, respectively (Fig. 2cef). Traces of a dendritic structure are seen inside grains in M2 and M4 alloys. It should be noted that M4 is a near equimolar composition of Mo, Nb and Ti and, therefore, it cannot be strictly called Nb-based alloy. Partial replacement of Mo with W in M4 produced the MW1 alloy, which contains traces (less than 1% by volume) of a secondary phase, which is located at or near grain boundaries of the BCC matrix phase and has dark contrast on backscatter images (Fig. 2g). The average diameter of the matrix grains is 59 mm. According to the EDS analysis, the composition of the matrix grains is close to the average alloy composition, while the secondary phase is rich in Ti (Table 4). EBSD phase analysis reveals BCC crystal structure of the Ti-rich secondary phase. All the alloys contain fine pores after casting. They are seen as black dots, mainly inside grains, on the backscatter images and are the most populated in C-3009 (Fig. 2a). The volume fraction of these pores does not exceed 0.1%; thus only minor effect of these pores on compression ductility can be expected. The density of the commercial alloy C-3009 measured with the use of a helium pycnometer is 10.3 g/cm 3 (Table 2). Replacement of Hf with Ti results in the W1 alloy with a reduced density of 8.6 g/ cm 3 . Additional replacement of W with Mo decreases the density even further, so that M1 alloy density is 7.96 g/cm 3 . Densities of M2 and M3 alloys, which have increasing amounts of Mo, are 7.99 and 8.03 g/cm 3 , respectively. Densities of the multi-principal component alloys M4 and MW1 are 7.83 and 9.11 g/cm 3 . Thus, the replacements of W and Hf with Mo and Ti have clear beneficial effects on reducing the alloy density.

div.head: Room temperature properties
div.p: Room temperature mechanical properties were studied using Vickers microhardness testing and compression testing. The measured microhardness (Hv) values are given in Table 5. Microhardness of C-3009 was 2.69 GPa. Replacement of Hf with Ti increased microhardness of W1 to 3.07 GPa. Microhardness of the developmental NbeMoeTi alloys increased with increasing the amount of Mo from 2.17 GPa for M1 to 3.81 GPa for M4. Partial replacement of Mo in M4 with W increased microhardness of MW1 to 4.94 GPa. One can see that microhardness of all the developmental alloys, except M1, was higher than that of C-3009, with the largest increase (~84%) in MW1.

The room-temperature true stress vs. true strain curves for the studied alloys are shown in Fig. 4a and the measured yield stress (s 0.2 ) and compression modulus (E) values are given in Table 5. At T ¼ 23 C, all the studied alloys showed continuous strengthening after plastic yielding. C-3009 had s 0.2 ¼ 663 MPa, while W1, in which Hf was replaced with Ti, had noticeably higher yield stress, s 0.2 ¼ 849 MPa. The NbeMoeTi alloy M1 had the smallest . s 0.2 (¼ 521 MPa) among the studied alloys, while s 0.2 vales of M2 and M3 (719 MPa and 780 MPa, respectively)) were between those for C-3009 and W1. The multi-principal element alloys M4 and MW1 were considerably stronger showing s 0.2 values of 1100 MPa and 1440 MPa, respectively. All the alloys, except M4 and MW1, showed homogeneous compression deformation, without any evidence of fracture. In the M4 and MW1 alloys, deformation localized inside macroscopic shear bands, which caused cracking and fracture along these bands at true compression strains of ~0.25 and 0.11, respectively, after achieving peak true stress values of 1757 MPa and 1900 MPa (Fig. 4a). Due to their reduced density, the developmental alloys showed specific yield stress values superior to the specific yield stress of C-3009 (Table 5).

The measured compression modulus E of C-3009 was 110 ± 20 MPa (Table 5). The error in the measurements was rather also calculated for the studied alloys and the calculated values are given in Table 5.

The measured microhardness and yield stress values were compared with the calculated elastic moduli of the respective alloys and useful relationships were found. In particular, the alloy microhardness was described as a linear function of the alloy bulk modulus and the yield stress roughly followed a linear dependence on the alloy shear modulus (Fig. 3b andc): The yield stress of a solid solution alloy, which contains obstacles for dislocation glide, with the obstacles' density b on the slip plane, can be described by the following equation [19]:

Here a is a constant, which depends on the type of obstacles and can vary from ~0.3 for weak obstacles (e.g. solid solutions) to 3.0 for strong obstacles (e.g. precipitates), b is the Burgers' vector value and G is the alloy shear modulus. Using a
div.formula: ¼ 1, b ¼ ffiffi ffi 3 p
div.p: 2 a, a ¼ a mes from Table 3, G ¼ G ROM and s 0.2 from Table 5, the obstacle density b at the beginning of the plastic deformation was estimated for the studied alloys and the calculated values are shown in Table 5. The calculated b are in the range from 1.53Â10 15 m -2 for alloy M1 to 4.95 x1015 m -2 for alloy MW1. These b values give the average distance between the obstacles of ~26 to 14 nm in the studied alloys. Such high number density of the obstacles in non-deformed singlephase alloys can only be related to solute atoms and their clusters. For example, the typical density of dislocation forest in annealed alloys is ~1x1011 to 3 x1012 m -2 , i.e. 3 to 4 orders of magnitude lower.

The observed increase in b with increasing the concentration of the alloying elements in the same alloy families also supports the solidsolution strengthening mechanism in these alloys. For example, the observed increase in s 0.2 with increasing the concentration of Mo in M1, M2 and M3 alloys can be described by a linear dependence (Fig. 3d):
Here C Mo is Mo concentration (in at.%) and s 0 ¼ 100 MPa is the yield stress at C Mo ¼ 0%.

div.head: Deformation behavior at elevated temperatures
div.p: The true stress vs. true strain deformation curves for the studied alloys at 600 C, 800 C, 1000 C and 1200 C are shown in Fig. 4. At these temperatures, W1, M1, M2, M3 and M4 did not fracture during deformation. MW1 had limited compressive ductility at 600 C, 800 C and 1000 C, but it did not fracture at 1200 C. C-3009 was ductile (did not fracture) at 600e1000 C, but it fractured after true strain of 0.3 at 1200 C.

At T ¼ 600 C and 800 C, deformation of C-3009, M1, M2 and M3 occurred with continuous strain hardening, while steady-state flow at almost constant flow stress was observed in W1 and M4 (Fig. 4 a,b). MW1 showed continuous decrease in true stress after reaching a peak stress s p ¼ 1227 MPa at ε p ¼ 0.12 (T ¼ 600 C) or s p ¼ 1115 MPa at ε p ¼ 0.16 (T ¼ 800 C), which resulted in fracture at ε f ¼ 0.3 (600 C) or 0.36 (800 C). At 1000 C and 1200 C, all the alloys showed strain hardening only at the beginning of deformation, up to ~0.1e0.18 true strain; then strain softening and/or steady state flow followed (Fig. 4 c,d). A considerable loss in compressive ductility was observed in C-3009 at 1200 C (Fig. 4 d). Visual observation of the tested C-3009 samples showed that this loss in compressive ductility was due to strain localization in a single ~45 -inclined shear band and fracturing along this band. Such behavior indicates deformation instability of C-3009 at 1200 C. Fine-grained structure and multiple cracks were observed inside this shear band. It is likely that formation of fine-grained structure within the shear band was responsible for strain localization and cracking. The fine-grain structure initiated extensive grain boundary sliding, which, however, was not yet accommodated by dislocations and diffusion inside grains, and this resulted in crack formation at triple junctions and along grain boundaries. By growing and merging, these micro-cracks led to macroscopic fracture. Obviously, the strain hardening capability of the alloy is not sufficient to initiate plastic deformation on 5 independent slip systems needed for homogeneous shape change.

During heating from 23 C to 600 C, all alloys showed considerable drop in s 0.2 (Tables 5 and6). For example, s 0. and at 1200 C s 0.2 of W1 was twice smaller than that of C-3009 (Table 6). This result indicates that although the replacement of Hf with Ti makes the alloy stronger at room temperature, probably due to increasing elastic moduli, the Ti-containing alloy becomes softer at high temperatures, probably because of reduced melting temperature (Table 1, Table 5). The M1 alloy, which contains 17.8% Ti and 9.2% Mo, was the least strong alloy at all the studied temperatures. It had s 0.2 ¼ 170 MPa and 97 MPa at 1000 C and 1200 C, respectively. The hightemperature strength increased almost linearly with increasing the amount of Mo in M1, M2 and M3 alloys, and M3, which has 14.1% Mo, had s 0.2 ¼ 270 MPa and 183 MPa at 1000 C and 1200 C, respectively (Table 6). It is evident that solid solution strengthening is a dominant strengthening mechanism in these alloys at all the studied temperatures. The multi-principal element alloys, M4 and MW1 were considerably stronger than the other developmental alloys at all the studied temperatures (Table 6). Moreover, s 0.2 of M4 was higher than that of C-3009 at all temperatures but 1200 C and s 0. all temperatures except 1200 C. It is, however, necessary to point out that the properties of all the alloys were studied in as-cast condition and their compressive ductility is expected to increase after refining the microstructure by thermomechanical processing.

div.head: Using atomistic simulations to predict strength of refractory alloys
div.p: Recently Rao et al. [20,21] combined an analytical Suzuki model [22,23] with atomistic simulations of solute e screw dislocation core interaction energies to calculate the yield stress and predict its temperature dependence in several refractory-based complex concentrated alloys with a single-phase BCC crystal structure. Atomistic simulations were used to determine the solute e screw dislocation interaction energies, whereas the Suzuki model briefly described in the following paragraph, was used to determine the temperature dependence of the yield behavior using atomistic information.

The Suzuki model assumes that in concentrated BCC alloys kink pairs nucleate easily on screw dislocations while the kink migration along the screw dislocation line controls the rate of dislocation motion. Suzuki derived the activation energy for kink migration as [20e23]:
div.formula: DH(t k ) ¼ 3cE w 2 k 2 /(2t k ab 2 ) e t k 3 a 3 b 4 L k 2 /(18k 2 E w 2 c)(5)
div.p: Where c is the concentration of solutes, E w is the solute-screw dislocation first and second neighbor interaction energy, b is the Burgers vector of the screw dislocation, a ~0.942b, L k is the kink width, t k is the resolved shear stress for the kink migration and k is derived from the following equation [22,23]:
div.formula: 1 ffiffiffiffiffiffi 2p p ð ∞ k exp À x 2 2 dx ¼ b 3Lc (6
div.p: Where L is the half-spacing between hard dipole obstacles on the screw dislocation. Using Orowan equation and taking the mobile screw dislocation density as (5pkT/mbDV) 2 , where DV is the activation volume [22,23], the strain rate, dε/dt can be written down as dε/dt ¼ nab (5pkT/mbDV) 2 exp(-DH(t k )/kT)

Where n is the Debye frequency, k is the Boltzmann constant and T is the temperature. The stress t k required to satisfy the applied strain rate in Equation ( 7) as a function of temperature plus the stress required to bow the screw dislocation between the hard dipole obstacles (~mb/4L), is then minimized with respect to L and the critical resolved shear stress to move the screw dislocation is determined as a function of temperature. The solute-screw dislocation interaction energy, E w , is obtained from atomistic simulations as detailed elsewhere [20,21]. The contribution from various solutes are then summed up according to a multi-component hardening law, as described in Refs. [20,21].

Here we apply the approach by Rao et al. [20,21] to calculate s 0.2 of the studied alloys at different temperatures in order to further estimate the level of prediction and limitations, as the Suzuki model does not take into account diffusion-controlling processes. A Taylor factor M ¼ 2.73, corresponding to a pencil-glide model in a texture-less BCC polycrystal [24], was used to convert the calculated critical resolved shear stress t k to the compression yield stress s 0.2 calc . , given in Table 6. The substitutional solute e screw dislocation interaction energies were obtained from atomistic simulations using simple Johnson-Zhou interatomic potentials [25,26] ) in M1 could be due to high Taylor factor (¼2.73) used in the calculations. Indeed, M ¼ 2.73 is generally valid for randomly oriented polycrystalline structures. On the other hand, the M1 alloy consisted of very large grains, and the small number of grains in the compression samples could effectively reduce the Taylor factor closer to that of softer orientations [27]. Indeed, the calculations for M1 would well agree with the experiment if M ¼ 2.25 were used. The large deviation of the calculated s 0.2 values from the experimental ones for the multi-principal element alloy M4 could be due to errors in the atomistic calculations of the solute e screw dislocation interaction energy parameters, e.g. due to neglecting far-neighbor interactions. First principles calculations need to be used for a more rigorous calculation of these quantities [28]. The experimental data in Table 6 seems to show a faster decrease of s 0.2 between 1000 C and 1200 C, as compared to the Suzuki model results (Table 7). The large deviation between the experimental and calculated values at 1200 C is likely due to the onset of diffusion-controlled processes, which the Suzuki model does not consider [20]. Thus the Suzuki model can satisfactory predict yield stress of the Nb refractory alloys at temperatures 1000 C, but it fails at higher temperatures, when the diffusion-controlled processes start to dominate.

div.head: Improving specific strength
div.p: Although the yield stress of C-3009 was superior to the developmental alloys W1, M1, M2 and M3 at T ! 600 C, its specific yield stress, due to higher density, lagged up to 1000 C (Table 6, Fig. 5).

For example, at room temperature, s 0.2 /r of C-3009 and M1 are the same (¼65.5 MPa cm 3 /g) and much smaller than those of W1, M2 and M3. At 600 C, s 0.2 /r of C-3009 is similar to M2 but smaller than that of M3 and W1. At 800 C, s 0.2 /r of C-3009 is almost similar to that of M3; but at T ! 1000 C, C-3009 became superior to these three Mo-containing alloys. At the same time, s 0.2 /r of W1 is superior to M1, M2, M3 and C-3009 ate temperatures up to 1000 C. The specific yield stress values of M4 and MW1 are considerably higher than those of all other studied alloys, including C-3009. It is apparent that solution strengthening of Nb by Mo is noticeably weaker than by W. Alloying with higher amount of Mo is required to achieve the strengthening effect similar to W. At the same time, Ti provides stronger strengthening effect than Hf at room temperature; however, the advantage is lost above 800 C.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Six new Nb-based refractory alloys containing W and Ti (W1) or Mo and Ti (M1, M2, M3 and M4) or Mo, Ti and W (MW1) were produced and their microstructure and compression properties in the temperature range of 23e1200 C were reported and compared with commercial C-3009. The produced alloys, except MW1, had single-phase BCC crystal structures. MW1 had small fraction of Ti-rich precipitates located at grain boundaries. While chemical micro-segregation was clearly observed in the cast C-3009, replacement of Hf with Ti and W with Mo led to more homogeneous distribution of the alloying elements in the developmental alloys. In Mo-containing alloys, the average grain size decreased with an increase in the amount of Mo.

The densities of the produced Nb alloys were considerably smaller than the density of C-3009 (10.3 g/cm 3 ). Alloy M4 had the smallest density (¼7.70 g/cm 3 ) and MW1 had the largest density (¼8.94 g cm 3 ) among the reported alloys.

W-containing alloys (C-3009, W1 and MW1) were stronger than Mo-containing alloys at T ¼ 600e1200 C. With increasing temperature in this temperature range, Mo-containing alloys lost their strength quicker than W-containing alloys.

Alloying with Hf had beneficial effect on high-temperature strength relative to alloying with Ti; however, the effect from Ti was stronger at room temperature. On the other hand, alloying with Ti reduced the alloy density and increased specific strength at higher temperatures.
At all the studied temperatures, the strength of Mo-containing alloys increased almost linearly with increasing Mo concentration evidencing solid-solution strengthening.

Atomistic simulation based on Suzuki's model can satisfactory predict yield stress of the Nb refractory alloys at temperatures 1000 C, but it fails at higher temperatures, when the diffusioncontrolled processes start to dominate.

Due to reduced density, the room temperature specific strengths of the developmental alloys were superior to that of C-3009. Specific strengths of M4 and MW1 were superior to C-3009 and all other reported alloys at all the studied temperatures.

Elastic properties (Young's modulus E ROM , shear modulus G ROM and bulk modulus B ROM ) calculated using rule of mixtures, as well as the calculated number density of obstacles b, are also given here.

note.p: high due to displacement signal noise. Replacement of Hf with Ti increased E to 133 GPa (alloy W1). The Nb-9.2Mo-17.8Ti alloy M1 had E ¼ 125 GPa. Continuous increasing the amount of Mo led to an increase in E to 129 GPa, 138 GPa and 183 GPa in alloys M2, M3 and M4, respectively. The alloy MW1, which additionally contained W, was the stiffest, with E ¼ 193 GPa. The measured E values were similar to the E ROM values (Table5) calculated using the rule of mixtures of the Young's moduli of the pure elements from Table1. These findings are in good agreement with earlier publications by Tian et al.[17] and Yao et al.[18] who used first-principle (FP) methods to calculate elastic moduli of many refractory BCC solid solution alloys and found that the calculated elastic constants are very close to those calculated using the rule of mixtures. Using the rule of mixtures, shear modulus G ROM and bulk modulus B ROM were
